title: 2023 Energy Efficiency Standards for Air Conditioners and Heat Pumps
description: The US Department Of Energy updated energy efficiency standards for room air conditioners and portable air cleaners in 2023. The new rules will come into effect in 2024 for air cleaners and 2026 for room air conditioners.

title: UK Budget 2020 - Heat Networks Investment Project
description: The government added GBP 96 million to the budget for the last year of the scheme, which ends in March 2022.  A further GBP 270 million will be invested in a new Green Heat Networks Scheme. It will enable new and existing heat networks to switch to low carbon sources and connect to waste heat that would otherwise be released into the atmosphere.
type: Government spending for efficient or cleaner technologies,Incentives and investments

title: UK Plan for Jobs - Green Homes Grant
description: The government will introduce a £2 billion Green Homes Grant, providing at least £2 for every £1 homeowners and landlords spend to make their homes more energy efficient, up to £5,000 per household.  For those on the lowest incomes, the scheme will fully fund energy efficiency measures up to £10,000 per household. In total this could support over 100,000 green jobs and help strengthen a supply chain that will be vital for meeting our target of net zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2050.  According to news reports, the grant covers the following technologies: Loft and floor insulationNew, more efficient boilersHeat pumpsEnergy-efficient lightingDouble or triple glazed windowsEnergy-efficient doors Tradespeople must register for TrustMark accreditation to take part in the scheme to ensure sufficient training. As of March 27, 2021: The UK Ten Point Plan extended the program by one year with GBP 1 billion of additional funding. However total spending for green home upgrades in energy efficiency will amount to 1.3 billion GBP, 300 million GBP more compared to the initial budget. The new funding will be delivered to local authorities and will help lower income households cut emissions whilst saving money on bills, helping country build back greener. The Green Homes Grant voucher scheme closed on March 31st, 2021.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: UK Plan for Jobs - Public Sector Decarbonisation Scheme
description: The Clean Growth Strategy (published 2017) set out the government’s ambition to halve greenhouse gas emissions from the public sector by 2032.  To help achieve this and support economic recovery, the government invested £1 billion in 2020 in a Public Sector Decarbonisation Scheme that will offer grants to public sector bodies, including schools and hospitals, to fund both energy efficiency and low carbon heat upgrades. It was followed by £75 million of funding for 2021/2022 then £1.425 billion for 2022/2025.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: UK Plan for Jobs - Courts and Tribunals estate sustainability
description: The government will invest £40 million to improve the environmental sustainability of the courts and tribunals estate in England and Wales, investing in initiatives to reduce energy and water usage.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: UK Plan for Jobs - Social Housing Decarbonisation Fund
description: The government will establish a new Social Housing Decarbonisation Fund to help social landlords improve the least energy-efficient social rented homes, starting with a GBP 50 million demonstrator project in 2020-21 to decarbonise social housing. This will mean warmer homes and lower annual energy bills for some of the lowest income households. 23 August 2021, the government announced that local authorities and housing associations will have the chance to secure a share in a significant 160 million GBP cash injection through the Social Housing Decarbonisation Fund, to promote stronger energy efficiency of socially rented homes.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: Community Efficiency Financing Initiative (second phase)
description: The CAD 300 million Community Efficiency Financing initiative is designed to help municipalities and their partners implement innovative local financing programs to improve energy efficiency, cut greenhouse gas emissions and make homes more comfortable and affordable in low-rise residential properties.  Funding is provided by the Government of Canada and delivered by the Federation of Canadian Municipalities (FCM) through the FCM's existing Green Municipal Fund. The funding will be delivered via a 'bottom-up' approach to local program design, offering applicants the opportunity to study and design programs tailored to local priorities and contexts and may build on approaches such as Property Assessed Clean Energy (PACE) financing and utility on-bill financing.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: £1.3 billion investment to deliver homes, infrastructure and jobs
description: The government confirms a GBP 1.3 billion investment to deliver homes, infrastructure, and jobs. This funding focuses on efficient new construction, complementing the Green Homes Grant scheme, which targets energy efficiency retrofits.  GBP 900 million will go to the Getting Building Fund, to invest in shovel-ready housing and infrastructure projects. An additional GBP 360 million investment will go to building in brownfield areas, through the Mayoral Combined Authority's GBP 400 million Brownfield Fund.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: CAIF funding for school energy efficiency and retrofits
description: The Climate Action Incentive Fund (CAIF) MUSH Retrofit stream provides funding to municipalities, universities/colleges, schools, and hospitals to help them make energy efficiency improvements and retrofits.  This CAIF program is available in the provinces of Saskatchewan, Manitoba, Ontario, and New Brunswick. The first round of funding for 2019-2020 is intended to support energy efficiency projects in schools, with a budget of approximately CAD 60 million. Funding estimated at approximately CAD 5 million will be allocated to Manitoba, CAD 12 million to Saskatchewan, and CAD 40.8 million to Ontario.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: Investment in Alberta construction industry for energy efficiency and green building practices
description: The Federal Government is investing CAD 3 million in Alberta's construction and engineering industry through Western Economic Diversification Canada (WD). This investment will help small and medium-sized businesses adopt new products and technologies that improve the energy efficiency of buildings and reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. WD funding is complemented by an investment of more than $2.8 million from Alberta Innovates (public agency), in-kind support from industry and $165,000 from the Smart Sustainable Resilient Infrastructure Association (SSRIA), bringing the total project funding to over $6.3 million. Products and services expected to be commercialized include:- materials for walls, roofs and foundations;- mechanical and electrical system improvements;- sensors and lighting products that reduce energy consumption;- software for storing and analyzing performance on energy efficiency and GHG.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: Ten Point Plan for a Green Industrial Revolution - Point 7: Greener Buildings
description: As part of the ten point plan, the UK will develop increase buildings' energy efficiency.  The plan will increase funding by 1 billion GBP by:- extending the Green Homes Grant for another year, - increasing spending within the Public Sector Decarbonisation Scheme, - upgrading heat systems in rural areas through the Homes Upgrade Grant, - committing further funding for the Social Housing Decarbonisation Fund to continue upgrading the least efficient social housing.  The policy will also:- implement Future Home Standard (70-80% lower emissions than today),- consult on increased standards for non-domestic buildings,- upgrade EE standards of household products, including by launching an improved Energy Technology List website.  and move away from - reform pricing and regulations to reinforce the shift from fossil fueled boilers, especially for off-grid homes (target for 600 000 heat pump installations per year by 2028) - extend Energy Company Obligations for energy efficiency and addressing fuel poverty to 2026- introduce mandatory disclosure requirements for lenders on the energy performance of homes on which they lend and setting voluntary improvement targets.  Expected results: - Help improve EE of around 2.8 million homes- leverage around 11 billion GBP of private investment in the 2020s - savings of 71 MtCO2e between 2023 and 2032, or 16% of 2018 UK emissions 2021: set out Heat and Buildings Strategy 2021: Launch a world class energy related products policy framework. Push for products to use less energy, resources and materials, saving carbon and helping households and businesses to reduce their energy bills with minimum effort. By 2032: ensure that the public sector has reduced its direct emissions by 50% compared to a 2017 baseline.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: Government Bill 1991/92 - Sweden carbon tax
description: Sweden introduced a carbon tax in 1991. At the time, the price was SEK 250 (EUR 24) per tonne, and it has since increased to SEK 1 200 (EUR 114) in 2021. Before making any adjustments to its carbon pricing mechanism, the government in Sweden identifies groups that will be most impacted, and targets communication of the policy changes to their concerns. The gradual increase of the tax level also means that households and businesses are given enough time to adapt, which has improved the political feasibility of the increases and promoted trust in the carbon price. Any increase has also typically been combined with general tax relief in other areas for households and firms to avoid increases in the overall level of taxation, address undesirable distributional consequences and stimulate job growth.

title: Consolidated Appropriations Act
description: The bill contains measures to address climate change, such as limiting the use of a potent greenhouse gas in refrigerants and extending tax incentives for wind and solar energy. The bill provides USD 1.4 trillion to fund the US government through September 2021 as well as a USD 900 billion coronavirus aid package. Energy provisions contained in the bill include: - extending the 26% investment tax credit for solar systems on residential and commercial through 2023 and then continuing with the phasedown to 22% in 2024 and 10% in 2025- extending the onshore wind production tax credit by 1 year- extending tax credits by two years for fuel cell vehicles, biofuels, and alternative fuel infrastructure- extending through 2025 (two additional years) tax credits awarded on a per-ton basis for carbon dioxide that is sequestered- providing USD 90 million in grants for replacing older diesel-powered vehicles and equipment with cleaner-burning models, USD 3 million more funding from FY 2020. - provisions for mandatory reporting of methane emissions from animal manure- allowing the commercial building energy efficiency tax deduction, with the credit indexed to inflation and updated efficiency standards.- Requiring US companies to reduce the production of hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) to 15% of 2012 levels by 2036. - extending DOE National Lab funding and increasing total spending by USD 1 billion- extending for five years the 9 cents per barrel tax on oil that funds the Oil Spill Liability Trust Fund
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments,Government spending for low-emissions and efficient transport,Incentives and investments,Government spending in low-carbon electricity,Incentives and investments

title: Municipal Energy Roadmap
description: As part of the Green Municipal Fund initiative, the Municipal Energy Roadmap is a decision-support tool that provides strategic advice to find the most impactful solutions to reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. It will help municipalities: discover solutions for energy efficiency in municipal, commercial, and residential buildings; learn about solutions for community sustainable energy generation; implement strategies to drive these solutions forward. The initiative is part of the Green Municipal Fund, a CAD 1 billion program funded by the Government of Canada and delivered by the Federation of Canadian Municipalities.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: Infrastructure projects in the energy and water economies: 5. Action plan for an energy-efficient urban space
description: In response to the Covid-19 crisis, Israel's Ministry of Energy has identified 10 project areas to accelerate investment and support the economic recovery through ILS 25 billion of investment.   Among these policies, the fifth identified project area is an ILS 300 million action plan for energy efficient urban spaces in cities. This plan will enable the promotion of an efficient and clean energy environment, reduce urban pollution, help with tackling the climate crisis, incentivising innovation, adopting new technologies (smart homes, electrification of buildings in the city), economic savings and more. The project is expected to provide additional centres of energy resilience, to ensure the regular supply of electricity in the case of an emergency.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: A Healthy Environment and a Healthy Economy - Buildings energy efficiency
description: One of the five pillars of Canada's CAD 15 billion strengthened climate policy announced in December 2020 is focused on energy efficiency in buildings: Making the Places Canadians Live and Gather More Affordable by Cutting Energy Waste.Together, homes and buildings account for 13% of Canada’s greenhouse gas emissions. Electricity use for cooling, lighting and appliances brings the total to 18%. Constructing and renovating buildings creates jobs and lowers energy bills. Canadians also benefit from efforts to develop and deploy cutting-edge technologies that result in cleaner indoor air, higher resale values for homes and buildings, and less of an impact on their shared environment. This plan includes a focus on energy efficiency through: - CAD 2.6 billion over seven years for home retrofits under the Greener Homes initiative to provide up to 700 000 grants of up to CAD 5000 for home retrofits as well as supporting home energy assessments to advise on upgrades- CAD 1.5 billion over three years for municipal and community buildings- Stringent targets for embodied carbon and operational emissions for Government of Canada buildings - Commercial and large-scale building retrofits will be supported through the Canada Infrastructure Bank's CAD 2 billion energy efficiency retrofit fund- Investing in the tools to build a retrofit economy- Long-term infrastructure planning
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: Funding in microelectronic research
description: The Department of Energy (DOE) has announced USD 54 million of funding for the DOE's National Laboratories to advance research in microelectronics. National Laboratories may apply for the three-year awards, to be selected based on peer review. Up to USD 36 million of the USD 54 million is contingent on congressional appropriations.
type: Government spending for efficient or cleaner technologies,Incentives and investments

title: Community Buildings Retrofit (CBR) initiative
description: In April 2021, the Canadian Government launched the Community Buildings Retrofit initiative. Funded by a $167-million federal investment in the Federation of Canadian Municipalities' Green Municipal Fund, this programme will support Canadian municipalities and not-for-profit organizations to carry out retrofits and other upgrades to lower emissions by improving energy performance, lowering operating costs and extending the life of community buildings, such as arenas, pools, libraries and recreation and cultural centres. The Community Buildings Retrofit initiative will provide grants and loans to fund a portion of each project and expects to disburse the full funding envelope over the next six years, expecting to see the first capital projects approved before the end of 2021–22. This new initiative is part of a $950-million federal investment in the Green Municipal Fund designed to scale up energy efficiency and lower emissions across Canada.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: National Plan for Recovery and Resilience - Component 1.1: Renovation of buildings
description: Component 1.1 of the Belgian National Plan for Recovery and Resilience targets public and private building renovation (notably social housing) to improve energy efficiency. A public budget of 1,578 million EUR is allocated to this component to directly finance renovations, or to implement a revised regime of targeted subsidies.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: National Plan for Recovery and Resilience - Component 1.2: Emerging energy technologies
description: Axis 1 of the Belgian National Plan for Recovery and Resilience targets climate, sustainability and innovation. Component 1.2 aims at supporting emerging energy technologies, with two main regulation streams: - encouragements to the development of non-fossil based hydrogen and carbon markets,  - a reform of fossil fuel subsidies,  Six main investments are planned: - Hydrogen and CO2 infrastructure - Value chain for hydrogen economy  - Development of low emission industry  - Platform for research in energy transition technologies  - Network for renewable heat EUR  - Offshore energy island A public budget of EUR 2,104 million is allocated to this component.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments,Government spending in low-carbon electricity,Incentives and investments

title: Recovery and resilience plan / Energy renovation of buildings/ Investments in energy renovation of buildings
description: As part of the French Resilience and Recovery plan, EUR 6.7 billion were earmarked for measures specifically dedicated to energy upgrades, in an effort to reduce emissions and improve the energy efficiency in buildings. These measures include:  - MaPrimeRénov' programme for private households (2021-2022), to improve buildings, in particular energy upgrades as well as creating jobs in building renovations. - Upgrading public sector buildings, responsible for 25% of residential emissions in France. Part of the funding will be delegated to regions. - Energy efficiency upgrades for social housing (notably heating system improvements).  - Energy renovation of SMEs, to improve thermal insulation and energy efficiency.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: Sweden's Recovery Plan / energy efficiency of apartment buildings
description: This is the third component of the green recovery measures of Sweden's recovery and resilience plan. According to current proposals to the regulation, support is given to apartment buildings with an energy performance which, expressed as a primary energy figure, exceeds 100 kWh / m2, and year and for energy efficiency measures that improve the overall building's energy performance by at least 20 percent. The estimate of the target is based on the assumption of an annual renovation rate of three percent.     By 2023, support will have been granted for projects involving a total of 2 850 000 square meters.The total cost for 2021–2023 amounts to SEK 4.05 billion from RRF.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: Investments for household energy efficiency
description: Over 44 million GBP of funding will be allocated to cut emissions from buildings and help households save on energy bills. The investment is expected to cut carbon emissions by 22% for homes and buildings, whilst providing potential reductions of up to 15% in energy costs.  30 million GBP will fund 3 innovative heat network projects in London, Manchester and Cambridgeshire, and a further 14.6 million GBP announced will benefit 11 projects in England, Scotland and Wales. The funding will be invested in exploring ways the UK can develop and use efficient, low-carbon technologies for heating and cooling buildings.  The investments are tied to the government's Heat and Buildings Strategy, which will set out how carbon emissions in homes and workspaces will be addressed to meet legal commitments over achieving net zero emissions 2050.
type: Government spending for efficient or cleaner technologies,Incentives and investments

title: Resolution 286 on pricing of greenhouse gas emissions
description: The government of Israel announced the plan to introduce a carbon tax at slowly increasing level from 2023 to 2028 through a statement approved by the Tax Authority and the Finance, Energy, Environmental Protection and Economy ministries.  The nation’s first carbon tax will be applied to coal, liquified petroleum gas, fuel oil, petcoke and gas and is expected to cover about 80% of greenhouse gas emissions by 2028. However, the tax would not be introduced if the electricity price would rise by more than 5% through 2028. Additionally, diesel and gasoline will not be taxed any further as part of the scheme, due to existing levies.  At a later stage, the tax will cover the emissions from other sources of global warming gases, such as garbage dumps, responsible for 8% of Israel’s GHG emissions, and cooling gases used in air conditioning systems, refrigerators, and refrigerated vehicles, which account for 7% of GHG emissions.

title: Net Zero Strategy - Heat Pumps Ready Programme
description: The UK government invested an additional £60 million into heat pump innovation as part of the net zero innovation portfolio, making them more beautiful, smaller, and easier to install.It is part of the UK's plan to install 600,000 heat pumps per year by 2028 and expand UK manufacturing.  The Heat Pump Ready Programme is split into 3 separate delivery streams: Stream 1: solutions for high-density heat pump deployment. Up to £30 million of Small Business Research Initiative (SBRI) funding from spring 2022 to support the development and trial of solutions and methodologies for the optimised deployment of domestic heat pumps at high-density. Stream 2: developing tools and technology. Up to £25 million of grant funding for projects to overcome barriers to heat pump deployment, beginning spring 2022 Stream 3: trial support and learning. Up to £5 million contract from spring 2022 to provide support to ensure knowledge transfer and shared learning across the Heat Pump Ready Programme. This stream will provide support to the Stream 1 projects, joining-up Stream 2 technology and tools with their the Stream 1 projects where relevant and establishing working groups to collaborate on shared elements of deployment.
type: Government spending for efficient or cleaner technologies,Incentives and investments

title: Infrastructure and Jobs act: Energy Efficiency
description: As part of the U.S. Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act, measures related to Energy Efficiency coming from Title V Energy Efficiency and Building infrastructure represent a total budget of $1.025 billion.-Energy Efficiency Revolving Loan Fund Capitalization Grant program to conduct commercial or residential energy audits or upgrades and retrofits: USD 250 million -Competitive grant program within the Building Technologies Office to enable sustained, cost-effective implementation of updated building energy codes: USD 225 million-Award grants to nonprofits to equip their buildings with energy-efficiency materials: USD 50 million-Competitive grant program for schools to make EE improvements, install renewable energy, install alternative vehicle charging/fueling infrastructure: USD 500 million
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: Greener Neighbourhood Pilot Program
description: The Greener Neighbourhood Pilot Program aims to provide energy efficient retrofits to groupings of buildings at the same time. CAD 33.2 million is provided over 5 years to Natural Resources Canada to implement this program in up to 6 community housing neighbourhoods, in order to promote energy efficiency.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: Deep Retrofit Accelerator Initiative
description: The Deep Retrofit Accelerator Initiative aims to provide support for retrofit audits, and projects that accelerate the pace of deep retrofits in Canada. CAD 200 million is provided over 5 years to Natural Resources Canada to improve energy efficiency through retrofits with a focus on low income affordable housing.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: Support for greener homes loan and grants programmes under 2030 Emissions Reduction Plan
description: Under the 2030 Emissions reduction plan, additional provisions will be provided for the Greener Homes Loan Program. CAD 458.5 million is made available to help Canadians reduce emissions through renovations for heating and cooling systems.  The Canada Greener Homes Grant offers up to $5,000 to help homeowners cover the costs of eligible energy-efficient home retrofits, plus up to $600 for pre- and post-retrofit EnerGuide evaluations. The Canada Greener Homes Loan provides interest-free financing up to $40,000 for homeowners to undertake energy-efficient upgrades recommended by an energy advisor.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments,Government spending for efficient or cleaner technologies,Incentives and investments

title: Package to tackle the energy price crisis
description: In an effort to cushion domestic consumers from the effects of the global energy crisis, the Swedish government has enacted the following measures as an amendment to its 2022 budget:The tax on diesel and petrol is temporarily reduced from June to October 2022.A new fuel compensation is introduced for private individuals.Funding for energy efficiency improvements and renovation of apartment buildings and outdoor environments.Additional funds are allocated to the climate bonus appropriation incentivising the purchase of electric vehicles.the GDP indexation of diesel and petrol is paused.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments,Government spending for low-emissions and efficient transport,Incentives and investments

title: Canada invests CAD 2 million in energy efficiency for buildings in Ontario
description: Canadian government will invest over CAD 2 million to three residential building projects in Ontario to improve energy efficiency. The federal funding comes from Natural Resources Canada’s Green Infrastructure – Energy Efficient Buildings Program, which serves to improve homes and buildings in terms of design, renovation and construction. The government is also developing a Green Buildings Strategy, targeting increased building retrofits rate, resilient and net-zero ready buildings, and future systematic change in the buildings sector.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: Inflation Reduction Act 2022: Sec. 13301 Extension, Increase, and Modifications of Non-business Energy Property Credit Energy Property Credit
description: The U.S. Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 extends the existing tax credit for residential energy efficiency improvements and expenses and increases the credit value for certain heat and cooking sources.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments,Government spending for efficient or cleaner technologies,Incentives and investments

title: Inflation Reduction Act 2022: Sec. 13303 Energy Efficient Commercial Buildings Deduction
description: The U.S. Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 amends energy efficient commercial building tax deduction to decrease stringency of efficiency standards and outlines the value of deductions for various groups.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: Inflation Reduction Act 2022: Sec. 13304 Extension, Increase, and Modifications of New Energy Efficient Home Credit
description: The U.S. Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 extends a tax credit for contractors who build and sell energy-efficient homes and for homes that meet various Energy Star efficiency standards.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: Inflation Reduction Act 2022: Sec. 22002 Rural Energy for America Program
description: The U.S. Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 allocates USD 1.977 billion to fund up to 50% of projects eligible under section 9007 of the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002, especially those boosting applications of underutilized renewable energy technologies.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments,Government spending in low-carbon electricity,Incentives and investments

title: Inflation Reduction Act 2022: Sec. 22004 USDA Assistance for Rural Electric Cooperatives
description: The U.S. Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 allocates USD 9.7 billion in funding for rural electricity cooperatives to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, increase energy efficiency, and improve accessibility and resiliency.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments,Government spending in low-carbon electricity,Incentives and investments

title: Inflation Reduction Act 2022: Sec. 30002 Improving Energy Efficiency or Water Efficiency or Climate Resilience of Affordable Housing
description: The U.S. Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 allocates USD 1 billion to the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development to fund sustainability improvements in affordable housing, including electrification, energy and water efficiency improvements, and climate resiliency measures.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments,Government spending in low-carbon electricity,Incentives and investments

title: Inflation Reduction Act 2022: Sec. 40001 Investing in Coastal Communities and Climate Resilience
description: The U.S. Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 allocates USD 2.6 billion to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) to fund climate resiliency measures, conservation, and restoration of coastal and marine areas.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: Inflation Reduction Act 2022: Sec. 50121 Home Energy Performance-Based, Whole-House Rebates
description: The U.S. Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 allocates USD 4.3 billion for grants to state energy offices to create and carry out Home Owner Managing Energy Savings (HOMES) programs that provide rebates for energy-saving efficiency retrofits in homes.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: Inflation Reduction Act 2022: Sec. 50122 High-Efficiency Electric Home Rebate Program
description: The U.S. Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 allocates USD 4.5 billion for states and Indian Tribes to create and carry out rebate programs for efficiency improvements and electrification in homes, including via retrofits and appliance upgrades.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments,Government spending for efficient or cleaner technologies,Incentives and investments

title: Inflation Reduction Act 2022: Sec. 50131 Assistance for Latest and Zero Building Energy Code Adoption
description: The U.S. Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 allocates USD 1 billion for grants to state- or local-level governments to update and achieve compliance with more stringent building energy codes.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: Renewable-based heating subsidy scheme for companies & subnational authorities
description: In the framework of its Economic and Social Resilience Plan, the French government increased by EUR 150 million the budget available for the Heat Fund for 2022 - supporting company, community and subnational authority projects developing renewable energy-based heating networks.An increase in funding was allocated to the Heat Fund in 2023, reaching EUR 520 million.
type: Government spending for efficient or cleaner technologies,Incentives and investments,Government spending for energy efficiency and recycling,Incentives and investments

title: Ma prime Rénov
description: In the framework of its Economic and Social Resilience Plan, the French government enacted an enlargement of "Ma prime Rénov", a revenue-based subsidy scheme aimed at boosting home retrofits, from mid-April 2022 to the end of the year. The scheme was later extended in 2023, and support for the installation of high-efficiency gas-based heating systems was then scrapped. In 2024, the scheme was further revised to better target low-revenue households and incentivize both one-off energy-efficient ameliorations (such as boiler upgrades) and more energy-efficient renovations combining several ameliorations.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: Investment in public building renovation
description: In the framework of its Economic and Social Resilience Plan, the French government is investing EUR 50 million to retrofit its public buildings in order to make them more energy-efficient, and reduce their gas consumption.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: Supplementary fiscal purchasing power measures Act 2022
description: Act of 1 July 2022 amending some tax laws (Supplementary fiscal purchasing power measures Act 2022) as promulgated in Official Gazette 2022, 286. On 23 March 2023, the Dutch government announced the following measures to contain rising energy prices:Raising the one-off energy allowance (energietoeslag) for people on incomes around the level of social assistance benefit to EUR 800.Lowering the rate of value-added tax (VAT) on energy from 21% to 9%. The reduced rate on electricity and gas will apply from 1 July through 31 December 2022.Excise duties on unleaded light oil (petrol), gas oil (diesel) and liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) will temporarily be reduced by 21% with retroactive effect to 1 April 2022 until 31 December 2022.Finally, the government is bringing forward spending of EUR 150 million, originally earmarked for 2026, to help low-income households take energy-saving measures.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: Boiler Upgrade Scheme
description: Formerly known as the Clean Heat Grant, the Boiler Upgrade scheme is a grant of GBP 5000 for homeowners to replace fossil fuel boilers with heat pumps. The scheme was extended to the 2025 -2028 period, with grant value increased to GBP 7500.
type: Government spending for efficient or cleaner technologies,Incentives and investments

title: Heat Pump Ready Programme
description: The Heat Pump Ready Programme forms part of BEIS’ GBP 1 billion Net Zero Innovation Portfolio (NZIP), which aims to accelerate the commercialisation of innovative clean energy technologies and processes through the 2020s and 2030s. Heat Pump Ready will support the development of innovative solutions across the heat pump sector.
type: Government spending for efficient or cleaner technologies,Incentives and investments

title: Public Sector Decarbonisation Scheme
description: Up to GBP 635 million of government funding made available to public sector organisations so they can install low carbon heating, such as heat pumps, and energy efficiency measures including double glazing and loft insulation. The funding is available through the Public Sector Decarbonisation Scheme with organisations such as NHS Trusts, schools and local authorities able to apply for grants from September 2022.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: VAT reduction on solar panels, solar water heaters and heat pumps
description: The Belgian government enacted in 2022 a temporary VAT reduction to the delivery and installation of the following energy-efficient technologies:Photovoltaic solar panelsThermal solar panelsSolar water heatersHeat pumpsDwellings being less than 10 years old are eligible to the reduced VAT rate of 6% (down from the standard 21%). The reduced rate is applicable between April 1, 2022, and December 31, 2023, inclusive.
type: Government spending for efficient or cleaner technologies,Incentives and investments

title: ProKilowatt programme
description: The Federal Council started the ProKilowatt programme in 2010, which provides state subsidies to electricity saving technologies in the industrial and service sectors, as well as for households.For 2022 (13th edition of the programme), applications for subsidies ran from 8th November 2021 to 16th October 2022.Examples of recipients for the 2022 support scheme includes a national support programme for the energy improvement of lighting. This programme aims to guarantee the quality of planning and the efficient implementation of lighting and control systems. For 2023, applications are opened since 7 November 2022 and will run until November 2023. As part of the 2023 edition, a separate bidding round will be organised for the first time for projects with an incentive contribution between CHF 2 million and 6 million.
type: Government spending for efficient or cleaner technologies,Incentives and investments,Government spending for energy efficiency and recycling,Incentives and investments

title: Increase to subsidy for renewable energy and energy savings 2022 (ISDE)
description: The ISDE subsidy (Investment Subsidy Renewable Energy and Energy Saving) is a yearly recurring program for insulation measures, (hybrid) heat pumps, solar power and connections to a heat network, which runs until 2030. In 2022, the budget of the ISDE is increased by EUR 62 million due to the large number of applications. This means that a total of EUR 290 million is available in 2022. Additionally, a budget of EUR 30 million is available in 2022 for small-scale wind turbines and solar panels.The increase in the subsidy will be available from 18 October 2022.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments,Government spending in low-carbon electricity,Incentives and investments

title: (California) Air Resources Board Cap and Trade Regulation
description: California's Cap-and-Trade Regulation was issued in 2012 to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases in different sectors and enforce the Greenhouse Gas Cap-and Trade Program. Its main objective is to continually incentivise investment in efficient technologies and processes that reduce or limit emissions. It is enforced by the California Air Resources Board (CARB).The Regulation establishes a limit for major sources of GHG emissions that declines each year; consequently, the Program applies an aggregate greenhouse gas allowance budget on covered entities. One allowance is equal to one metric ton of carbon dioxide equivalent emissions (Mt CO2-eq). Fewer allowances are created every year and the annual cap declines, reducing overall emissions in line with California's emissions targets.The Regulation also provides the procedure of a trading mechanism for compliance instruments. The Compliance Offset Program is also part of the Cap-and-Trade Program, through which CARB issues ARB Offset Credits to qualified projects that sequester greenhouse gases in accordance with Compliance Offset Protocols.

title: 2023 Social Housing Decarbonisation Fund and Home Upgrade Grant allocations
description: In 2023, the UK government is allocating dedicated funding to local authorities, providers of social housing and charities to subsidise energy-efficient home retrofits, with a focus on social housing, through both its Home Upgrade Grant scheme and the Social Housing Decarbonisation Fund (SHDF) .The Home Upgrade Grant targets around 25,000 low-income households across England.  The Wave 2.1 of the Social Housing Decarbonisation Fund aims at facilitating the implementation of energy performance measures in social homes located in England.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: Winter Energy Conservation Initiative
description: The Federal Council launched on August 2022 the Winter Energy Conservation Initiative. It includes the "Stop Waste" energy saving campaign and the Alliance for Energy Conservation. The initiative promotes energy saving measures through behavioural changes to save energy and to prevent a shortage. For 2022, a budget of CHF 14 million was allocated to the Winter Energy Saving Initiative. On December 2022, the Federal Council decided to continue the Winter Energy Conservation Initiative during the winter of 2023-2024. In March 2023, the Federal Council decided an additional CHF 7 million for the continuation of this initiative.
type: Government spending for efficient or cleaner technologies,Incentives and investments

title: Special programme for large-scale buildings renovations
description: The programme started in January 2021 and until 2023, 20 energy renovation interventions have been carried out, through loans amounting CHF 35 million. The Confederation agreed for a two-year extension of this special programme, until the end of 2025. The special programme provides loans for a duration of 25 years and amounts to 50,000 francs per dwelling. For the first ten years, the special programme gives interest-free loans to encourage public utility developers to renovate their residential buildings. Tenants must occupy their dwelling during the work of renovation.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: CO2 Act - CO2 levy
description: Switzerland introduced a CO2 tax on fossil fuels used in stationary sources in 2008. The levy covers around 40% of the country’s greenhouse gas emissions, primarily in the heating and process fuel sectors (fossil fuel for electricity generation – mainly small CHP and district heating – amounting to 1.2% of total generation). Two-thirds of Switzerland’s carbon tax revenues are returned to households and businesses through reductions in health insurance charges and social security payments.

title: Decree No. 2022-8 on the installation of heating equipments
description: From the 1st of July 2022, the installation of coal and oil boilers in new and existing buildings is forbidden in France.
type: Ban of oil boilers,Regulations,Ban of coal boilers,Regulations

title: Environmental regulations RE2020 - gas boiler installation ban
description: The environmental regulations RE2020 set new norms to the construction sector. It includes the ban of gas heating systems in new houses as of 1st January 2022. It does not cover other buildings.

title: Netherland's ban of gas boilers
description: The Dutch government announced in 2022 a switch of standards for heating, with hybrid heat humps becoming the norm from 2026 onwards. This eventually translates into a ban of gas boiler installation in new buildings by the same date.

title: Heat and building strategy - gas boilers phase-out
description: The United Kingdom plans to phase out the installation of new natural gas boilers beyond 2035 to ensure that all heating systems used in 2050 supports the net-zero ambition. UK is also exploring for all new natural gas boilers to be hydrogen compatible by 2026. Scotland is developing an advanced phase-out strategy as early as 2025.

title: Clean Growth Strategy - Oil, LPG and coal boilers phase-out
description: The United Kingdom initially aimed at phasing out the installation of oil, LPG and coal heating systems in new and existing off-gas-grid homes during the 2020s, with the goal of all heating systems to be low-carbon by 2050.Support for new LPG and oil heating systems was removed from 2022 onwards, but the sales ban was delayed to 2035 in September 2023.
type: Ban of oil boilers,Regulations,Ban of coal boilers,Regulations

title: The Buildings Program
description: The Buildings Programme launched in 2010 aims to significantly reduce the energy consumption and CO2 emissions of the Swiss building stock. Efforts include replacement of fossil fuels based heating systems or efficient use of thermal insulation building envelop. The programme remains to be a central element of Swiss energy and climate policy up to today.It is financed by funds collected from CO2 tax as well as cantonal subsidies.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: Artificial Intelligence (AI) for Decarbonisation Innovation Programme
description: The United Kingdom government is financing projects leveraging the deployment of new artificial intelligence (AI) solutions to accelerate industrial decarbonisation through improving industrial energy efficiency. The UK's first Center for Excellence on AI innovation for decarbonisation (ADViCE) was established to provide virtual hub that will bring together industries, academics, and experts to promote research on AI solutions for CO2 emissions in industrial sector. The fund will be granted through calls for proposals for AI solutions for decarbonization, such as ultra-low-power AI technology, AI supporting grid management, solar PV production forecasts, and agricultural robotics.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: New York City All-Electric Buildings Law
description: The mayor of New York City signed a local law to phase out the combustion of fossil fuel for heating in new residential and commercial buildings. The ban will be implemented from 2026 onwards.
type: Ban of oil boilers,Regulations,Ban of gas boilers,Regulations,Ban of coal boilers,Regulations

title: 2019 Climate Agreement - Gas-free homes Act
description: In its Climate Agreement, decided in 2019, the Netherlands aims to move away from gas in the building sector by 2050.

title: Executive Action to Spur Domestic Clean Energy Manufacturing by Invoking the Defense Production Act
description: In June 2022, President Biden issued a series of memoranda (Presidential Determinations 2022-15 through 2022-19) invoking the Defense Production Act of 1950 to spur domestic clean energy manufacturing and clean energy projects. These instruct the Department of Energy to take necessary action to rapid expand domestic manufacturing needs, specifically for:Solar panels and parts including modules and module components (Presidential Determination 2022-15);Insulation material (Presidential Determination 2022-16);Electrolyzers, Fuel Cells, and Platinum Group Metals (Presidential Determination 2022-17); andElectric Heat Pumps (Presidential Determination 2022-18)As of May 2024, two funding opportunities have been opened  for domestic heat pump manufacturers.
type: Government spending for efficient or cleaner technologies,Incentives and investments

title: 2014 budget law No. 2013-1278 - France carbon tax
description: The French carbon tax (Contribution Climat-Énergie or CCE) is attached to the domestic excise taxes on energy consumption (taxes intérieures sur la consommation des produits énergétiques, d’électricité et de gaz), increasing their overall rate. These excise taxes are added to the final price of petrol, diesel, heating oil or natural gas, so are paid by individuals and businesses. The carbon tax scheme serves as a complementary policy measure to the EU ETS: their respective scopes are complementary.Source: World Bank Carbon Pricing Dashboard

title: National Energy Code of Canada for Buildings (NECB) 2020
description: The National Energy Code of Canada for Buildings (NECB) 2020 sets out the technical requirements for the energy-efficient design and construction of new buildings and additions. This supersedes the 2017 edition which aimed at improving the level of energy efficiency provided by the code and to expand on the compliance options.The code sets minimum energy efficiency requirements, including net-zero energy ready-tiered performance levels for adoption by provinces and territories by 2030. The new code's targets are 10-15% more efficient than previous codes and 60%-70% more efficient at the highest tiers.
type: Building energy codes for new buildings,Regulations

title: Construction and Housing Code - Energy Performance Certificate
description: Buildings requirements are set through the new Code of Construction and Housing enacted in 2021. New constructions must respect the Energy Performance Diagnostic (DPE), equivalent to a performance certificate at the same time, by providing guidelines and minimum energy performance standards for building technologies.
type: Building energy codes for new buildings,Regulations

title: Israeli Standard for Green Building (No. 5281)
description: Under the Green Building Code, new buildings in Tel Aviv are required to have an EPI (Energy performance index) that is 25% lower than the baseline EPI for that building type, as defined by the Ministry of Environmental Protection. In addition, the Green Building Code requires that all new buildings in Tel Aviv be designed to be "green roofs ready", meaning that they are suitable for the installation of vegetation or other greenery on the roof to improve energy efficiency and reduce the urban heat island effect.
type: Building energy codes for new buildings,Regulations

title: Building decree 2012 (NEN 7120:2011)
description: The Dutch Building Decree requires minimum levels of energy performance for new buildings and renovations, following an energy performance coefficient.
type: Building energy codes for new buildings,Regulations

title: Sweden's Housing Building Rules
description: Sweden's Housing Building Rules was first implemented in 2011 with the latest amendment in 2020 complying with the 2018 European Union Energy Performance of Buildings Directive (EPBD). Additionally, it sets out requirements for the thermal insulation of building envelopes, heating systems, heating equipment efficiency standards, amongst others.
type: Building energy codes for new buildings,Regulations

title: Model Cantonal Regulations in the Energy Sector (MuKEn) standards
description: The Model Cantonal Regulations in the Energy Sector (MuKen) set energy regulations in the building sector for new builds, with notably a standard which amounts to 35 kWh/m2 for single and multi-family houses.The regulations were last updated in 2018.
type: Building energy codes for new buildings,Regulations

title: Building Regulations part L
description: Building regulation in England setting standards for the energy performance of new and existing buildings. All new buildings shall be nearly zero energy buildings.
type: Building energy codes for new buildings,Regulations

title: 2024 Energy efficiency call for project
description: The Swiss government allocated funding to energy efficiency -related projects implemented by companies or households.

title: Low Carbon Economy Fund- Indigenous Leadership Fund
description: The Indigenous Leadership Fund is one of the four funding stream within the Low Carbon Economy Fund. type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: Multi-dwelling energy efficiency and housing investment aid
description: The Government of Sweden aims to improve energy efficiency in multi-dwelling buildings through investment on promoting energy efficiency through increased energy performance and reduced energy demand and greenhouse gas emissions. description: Swedish government announced a SKK 320 million in 2025 to support energy-efficient technology and on investment aid for measures that lead to reduced electricity and gas use in households.

title: Built environment appliances energy efficiency
description: The Government of Netherlands is subsidising energy efficiency retrofit, including insulation works, the installation of solar boilers, heat pumps and electric cooking installations.
type: Government spending for efficient or cleaner technologies,Incentives and investments

title: Improved energy subsidy scheme -Brussels-Capital Region
description: The Belgian government is implementing an improved energy subsidy scheme meant to support efficient home renovations by low-income households in the Brussels-Capital Region.

description: The Belgian government is scaling up its budget allocation to a subsidy scheme meant to provide better home energy renovation incentives in Flanders.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments,Universal energy access,

description: The Belgian government is financing a new deployment of LED lights, charging stations and solar panels in the public buildings owned by the Federal State.

description: The Belgian government is investing in energy efficiency improvements of public regional, school, residential care and certain hospital buildings in Flanders.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: [REPowerEU]Public lighting upgrade
description: Public lighting will be upgraded with LED on motorways and in tunnels in the Flemish Region.

title: Building Environment Decree
description: The Building Environment Decree replaces the 2012 Building Decree, and  contains the technical regulations that represent the minimum requirements for all structures in the Netherlands.
type: Building energy codes for new buildings,Regulations

title: Tax credit for investments in green industries- Heat pumps
description: France introduced in 2024 a tax credit for industrial investments in 4 key sectors, as part of its Green Industry Law aimed at decarbonising the domestic industry, as well as developing domestic low-carbon production capacities. Battery, heat pump, wind and solar PV equipment new production projects across the entire value chain benefit from a 20% investment tax credit. Small and Medium-sized Enterprises, as well as project beneficiaries operating in regions recognised under the European Commission Regional Aid Guidelines (RAG), benefit from higher tax credit rates.A related EUR 2.9 billion State aid was approved in January 2024 by the European Commission under the State aid Temporary Crisis and Transition Framework to support measures in sectors which are key to accelerate the green transition and reduce fuel dependencies.

title: Energy Efficient Home Consumer Campaign
description: The Swedish Energy Agency, together with the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency, the National Board of Housing, Building and Planning, and the Swedish Consumer Agency is launched an energy efficiency campaign in 2007. The campaign demonstrates technical solutions that improve daily energy efficiency of Swedens residences. The campaign will provide information about the coming energy declarations and address both individual homeowners and owners of multi-dwelling buildings and premises as well as other relevant key players. The campaign continues during 2008.
type: Building energy codes for new buildings,Regulations

title: Ozone-depleting Substances and Halocarbon Alternatives Regulations
description: The Ozone-depleting Substances and Halocarbon Alternatives Regulations aim at setting norms over the import, export, production, use and sale of ozone-depleting substances such as F-gases. Last amendment in 2020 translates Kigali Amendment to the Montreal Protocol in the Canadian policy framework, with a scheduled phase-down of HFC consumption in the country.

title: The Fluorinated Greenhouse Gases Regulations
description: The regulations aim at setting the norms and targets for the export, import, production and use of ozone-depleting substances, notably F-gases.

title: American Innovation and Manufacturing Act
description: The act aims at phasing down the production and usage of HFCs, targeting a reduction of 85% by 2036.It notably sets rules and regulations for the import, export and production of HFCs.

title: Energy Efficiency Regulations, 2016 - Heat pumps
description: The energy efficiency regulations set standards for most appliances, including air conditioners, heat pumps and boilers. Standards for heat pumps were regularly updated, with last amendment enacted in 2022 (SOR/2022-265).

title: SI 16147 on heat pumps with electric compressors - tests, performance rating and marking requirements
description: The regulation specifies the norms for performance of heat pumps with electric compressors, including energy efficiency performance rating.

title: Codes Acceleration Fund (CAF)
description: Launched by Natural Resource Canada in January 2023, the Codes Acceleration Fund (CAF) supports sub-national governments in adopting the highest feasible energy performance tiers of the energy codes, or other high performance building codes, and to promote higher rates of code compliance.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: Green and Inclusive Community Buildings Program
description: The five-year $1.5 billion Green and Inclusive Community Buildings Program supports green and accessible retrofits, repairs or upgrades of existing public community buildings and the construction of new publicly-accessible community buildings that serve high-needs, underserved communities across Canada.The GICB Program supports the first pillar of Canada's Strengthened Climate Plan by improving the places Canadians live and gather by cutting pollution (e.g. reducing GHG emissions, increasing energy efficiency, building resiliency to climate change and encouraging new builds to net zero standards), making life more affordable and supporting thousands of good jobs.
type: Government spending for energy-efficient buildings,Incentives and investments

title: Chemical Risk Reduction Ordinance (ORRChem)
description: In Switzerland, refrigerants are regulated by Annex 2.10 of the Chemical Risk Reduction Ordinance (ORRChem). A key objective of the Ordinance is to reduce emissions of ozone depleting and potent climate-warming refrigerants. The Ordinance was last updated in July 2024.

title: The Ecodesign for Energy-Related Products and Energy Information Regulations
description: Following the United Kingdom's withdrawal from the European Union, the UK government retained EU legislation on Ecodesign and energy labelling for most energy related products, while adjusting legislation for some energy-related products in the Ecodesign for Energy-Related Products and Energy Information Regulations 2021.

title: Regulation on the requirements for the energy efficiency of mass-produced systems, vehicles and equipment

title: Canada Green Buildings Strategy - phase-out of the installation of oil heating systems
description: In its 2024 Green Buildings Strategy, Canada commits to introducing a regulatory framework that would allow the phase-out of the installation of oil boilers in new construction, as early as 2028.

description: This directive creates a new emissions trading system (ETS2) to cover CO2 emissions from fuel combustion in buildings, road transport and small industries not covered by the EU ETS. title: Energy Policy and Conservation Act
description: The Energy Policy and Conservation Act of 1975 aims to fulfil the United States' obligations under the International Energy Programme (IEP), to provide for the creation of a Strategic Petroleum Reserve, to conserve energy supplies, to provide for improved energy efficiency, to provide a means for verification of energy data, and to conserve water by improving water efficiency of certain plumbing products and appliances. The Strategic Petroleum Reserve provides for the storage of up to 1 billion barrels of petroleum products, maintained by the US Department of Energy (DOE). The US President may, if the President determines that declines in the production of oil from domestic resources pose a threat to national energy security, direct the US Secretary of Energy to acquire oil stocks from domestic producers of stripper well properties for storage in the SPR.

title: Swiss Emissions Trading Scheme and CO2 Tax
description: A Swiss Emissions Trading Scheme took effect on 1 January 2008, at the same time that a CO2 tax was introduced. The scheme is linked to voluntary agreements to reduce emissions under the pre-existing CO2 Law. Companies covered by voluntary agreements can convert these agreements into legally binding CO2 emissions targets, allowing them to participate in emissions trading and be exempted from the CO2 tax. Emission allowances are allocated to companies for free and from 2008, emission allowances equivalent to the amount of CO2 emitted have to be surrendered annually. Additional allowances can be sold. Where non-compliance occurs (i.e. where the adequate number of allowances is not surrendered) the CO2 tax is paid retroactively for each tonne of CO2 emitted since the exemption was granted.

title: Quebec Cap & Trade System for Greenhouse Gas Emissions Allowances
description: In 2009 Quebec established Cap and Trade System for Greenhouse Gas Emissions Allowances system in order to limit the emissions and encourage energy saving and growing shares of renewables in the consumption in the highest emitting sectors (i.e. transportation, industry and building). In December 2012 the system was updated with new rules entering into force in January 2013.The businesses that emit 25,000 metric tons or more of CO2 equivalent a year are subject to the cap-and-trade system. The first compliance period covered 2013 and 2014 and applied only to industrial and electricity sector. The second compliance period covered 2015-2017 and 2018-2020 periods and additionally applied to fossil fuel distributors.In addition, the cap-and-trade system is open to individuals and other entities that would like to participate in the carbon market, even if there is no regulatory obligation for them to do so.The Cap and Trade GHG emissions system is a centrepiece of Quebec’s climate action plan spanning the years 2013 to 2020.From 2013 Quebec’s carbon market was linked with California’s in order to improve liquidity of the market.
type: Emissions trading schemes and certified reduction credits,Incentives and investments,Carbon pricing instruments,Regulations

title: High efficiency buildings: SIA Building Code and Minergie Label Family
description: Since 1998, the Swiss Federal Office for Energy has worked in partnership with cantons to promote SIA building code (Norm SIA 380/1) and the Minergie label family. The standard, SIA 380, has been updated several times, most recently in 2016. Minergie is a voluntary energy-efficient construction standard for both new and renovated buildings . Buildings which meet the Minergie standards can then display the Minergie label. The SIA building code sets an overall limit on energy use for heating, hot water, ventilation and air-conditioning of 16 kWh /m2 for new and 24 KWh/m2 for renovated buildings. The Minergie Label is granted for buildings 20% below the acutal standard. Minergie also has standards for non-residential buildings (commercial, industrial, hospitals, sporting facilities etc.).

title: SI 994-1 Air conditioners: Safety requirements and performance requirements
description: This standard applies to air conditioners built from one unit: or more whose maximum rated output is 81 kW (air conditioners). This standard determines the requirements for the safety of air conditioners and the structure of the air conditioners.  This standard applies to single air conditioner and split air conditioner.

title: Green Municipal Fund
description: Beginning in 2000, the Government of Canada endowed the Federation of Canadian Municipalities with CAD 550 million to create the Green Municipal Fund, which stimulates investment in innovative municipal infrastructure projects and environmental practices for Canadian municipal governments and their public and private-sector partners.The Fund provides grants for cost-shared plans, feasibility studies, field tests and pilot projects, to improve the quality of air, water and soil through greater energy efficiency, the sustainable use of renewable and non-renewable resources and more efficient water, waste and waste water management. The Fund also supports the implementation of innovative environmental capital projects providing grants, loans and loan guarantees at competitive interest rates to municipalities and their partners. In addition, CAD 750,000 annually is allocated to the Green Municipal Capacity Building Program, which supports the Partners for Climate Protection program. In 2012, Green Municipal Fund eligibility was refined to target initiatives that aim to achieve significant environmental impacts and have the potential to be replicated in other communities.In 2023, the Community Efficiency Financing initiative was set up to help Canadian municipalities create, implement, and scale up home-energy upgrade financing programs for residential properties. With a $300 million investment, it supports various financing models like Property Assessed Clean Energy (PACE), utility on-bill financing, and third-party lending partnerships.

title: Oil to Heat Pump Incentive Program
description: Canada's Oil to Heat Pump Incentive Program Rebates helps homeowners who are currently heating their homes with oil, transition to eligible heat pump systems. A primary heating system is defined as a heating system with the capacity to heat a minimum 50% of the home for the entire heating season to 21oC. If the oil heating system is not functional, the home is not eligible for the Program rebate. Homes must be low-rise detached or semi-detached (single family home, row homes, townhouses, or mobile homes on a permanent foundation). Multi-unit residential buildings such as high-rises, apartment buildings, stacked duplexes, triplexes, and fourplexes are not eligible for the Program. Off-grid communities that are served by 100% diesel-powered generation are not eligible. Other off-grid communities may be eligible, but must be approved by the Ministry of Energy and Mines before proceeding.

title: (British Columbia) Carbon Tax Act
description: B.C.’s broad-based carbon tax puts a price on greenhouse gas emissions. This provides an incentive for sustainable choices that produce fewer emissions. The escalating tax was phased in on July 1, 2008. Beginning April 1, 2018, B.C.'s carbon tax rate is $35 per tonne of carbon dioxide equivalent emissions. The tax rate will increase each year by $5 per tonne until it reaches $50 per tonne in 2021. New revenue generated from the increasing carbon tax is used to protect affordability, maintain industry competitiveness, and encourage new clean initiatives.

title: Property tax exemption
description: In order to support the energy efficient and low-carbon retrofitting of houses in France, the French government introduced a 50% to 100% property tax exemption for housing energy work in some cities (subnational entites being final decision makers) for three years. Eligible works include:    - thermal insulation  - renewable energy equipment and heat pumps  - connection to district heating if the district network is fuelled by renewables or combined heat and power generation   - heat regulation equipment       Related spending in eligible categories of work should be greater than 10,000€ over the previous year, or greater than 15,000€ over the three previous years.
